{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3422474,"name":"Sean","username":"wallefan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-10T22:04:53.184Z","cooked":"

My team is building an offseason robot (for showing off at recruiting events) consisting of a basic west coast drive frame with a recliner chair mounted on top. The person sitting in the recliner holds the joystick to control the ‚Äúrobot‚Äù. (We‚Äôre calling it the world‚Äôs fastest couch.) Having an entire Windows computer with its own independent battery sitting on the robot communicating via WiFi to the same robot seemed a little silly to us, plus we wanted to learn something new, so we decided to replace the entire RoboRIO/driver station combo with a Raspberry Pi with a Waveshare CAN bus controller attached. We were hoping to write some custom Python code that would take input from a USB joystick and talk to the motor controllers directly via the CAN hat. Information on how to control the CTRE devices from anything that isn‚Äôt a RoboRIO running the official FRC firmware is remarkably sparse, and if CTRE has published documentation on the communication protocols their devices use below the library level, or source code to their Phoenix libraries for the RoboRIO, I can‚Äôt find it.

  1. Has anyone tried this before? If so, how did you get it working?
  2. Are there any available resources for this protocol, or getting the actual Phoenix libraries to work on a non-roboRIO CAN bus, or would we be better off rigging up a CAN bus sniffer and trying to reverse engineer it? I‚Äôm up for that if necessary, but if there‚Äôs an easier way I‚Äôd really rather not.
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":48,"updated_at":"2024-09-10T22:10:43.007Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":542,"reads":547,"readers_count":546,"score":2829.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":471033,"topic_slug":"controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio","display_username":"Sean","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/cheap-usb-to-can-bridge/473172/12","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Cheap USB to CAN bridge","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67844,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio/471033/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3422478,"name":"Dalton","username":"daltzsmith","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/daltzsmith/{size}/206287_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-10T22:29:21.932Z","cooked":"

Hi.

We actually natively support our devices outside of FRC for any generic socketcan adapter, or a CANivore. We also publish examples on our GitHub: CTR Electronics ¬∑ GitHub

Information can be found in the installation section in our documentation. If you find some information lacking, please let us know.

Phoenix 6

Getting Started

Hardware & Software Requirements Get started with the requirements to use Phoenix. These requirements highlight the supported devices, API targets, and SocketCAN adapters. Requirements Installing P...

Or if you are using an v5 device such as an SRX:

v5.docs.ctr-electronics.com

Prepare Linux Robot Controller

Why prepare Linux Robot Controller?: Preparing a Linux robot controller allows CAN Device control without a roboRIO for non-FRC use or as a secondary processor that can also directly control CAN De...

Unfortunately, we do not publish our CAN framing due to incidents of IP theft in the past.

One thing that you‚Äôre probably about to hear a lot of: SAFETY needs to be paramount for this type of build. You may have a fast robot+recliner with a person on top of it. What could happen if someone is on it tooling around in a parking lot and hits a car bump stop?

I can think of at least 3 failure modes that could result in serious injury, or fatality. All three have methods of preventing the failure or minimizing the injury. I would suggest taking a look at those methods‚Ä¶

Taking wireless control out of the loop is a step in a safer direction (minimizes control lag, makes it much harder for someone to remotely gain control). But the hardware should probably follow suit. There were two or three threads a few months ago about building robots with chairs on them (or wheelchairs), and the safety implications thereof. If you can‚Äôt find them I‚Äôm sure someone will link them soon enough.

I would say I‚Äôm sorry for the minor thread hijack, but I don‚Äôt apologize for trying to make sure people are safe.

Is there any reason pwm won‚Äôt work for you? I did something similar with 4 talon srxs and a vex hub just using pwm

Thank you for the prompt response! By the way, I didn‚Äôt see any examples or documentation on communicating with the CTRE PDP (read battery voltage, motor current etc.) Did I miss that somewhere?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":48,"updated_at":"2024-09-11T00:01:40.172Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":362,"readers_count":361,"score":97.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":471033,"topic_slug":"controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio","display_username":"Sean","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":61981,"username":"daltzsmith","name":"Dalton","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/daltzsmith/{size}/206287_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67844,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio/471033/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3422539,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-11T01:51:13.240Z","cooked":"

Been there, done that. I had tried a CANIvore attached to my jetson nano running Phoenix 6 python library controlling motor. I had also tried CANable controlling motors, all with success. If you use robotpy with CTRE libraries, the experience should be pretty similar. All documents on phoenix library should work.

I would also point out that as you needs to disable FRC lock (if those motor had attached to roboRIO before) and send hartbeat packet (feed enable) to keep your motor moving, These are safety feature built in to CTRE‚Äôs stuff.

Also as @EricH mentioned,

EricH:

One thing that you‚Äôre probably about to hear a lot of: SAFETY needs to be paramount for this type of build.

You will have to design a safe way to have your robot disabled in case your software run into some issue. Some of the cheapest way of doing this is hooking up a wireless relay box to your respberry pi‚Äôs power lead but in the end it is up to you to evaluate the best way to impliment safety feature.

We did think about that. Since we‚Äôre not confident that the motors will actually stop if the Pi locks up, we‚Äôre mounting the master battery interruptor (switch between the battery and the PDP) somewhere the person in the recliner can easily press it.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":48,"updated_at":"2024-09-11T01:54:20.994Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":307,"readers_count":306,"score":121.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":471033,"topic_slug":"controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio","display_username":"Sean","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":66330,"username":"NathanZhou","name":"Nathan Zhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67844,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio/471033/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3422544,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-11T02:03:39.919Z","cooked":"

Actually you could use some of these setup in FRC, if you had read team 195‚Äôs ROS implementation. But there will be some limit.

  • You have to have roboRIO attached, sending Enable packet to CAN network per

R714 Control CAN motor controllers from the roboRIO. Each CAN motor controller must be controlled withsignal inputs sourced from the roboRIO and passed via either a PWM (wired per R713) or CAN bus(either directly or daisy-chained via another CAN bus device) signal, but both shall not be wiredsimultaneously on the same device.
As long as the CAN bus is wired legally so that the heartbeat from the roboRIO is
maintained, all closed loop control features of the CAN motor controller may be
used. (That is, commands originating from the roboRIO to configure, enable, and
specify an operating point for all CAN motor controller closed loop modes fit the
intent of R701).

  • You can‚Äôt have a joystick hooked up or wirelessly connected directly to your coprocessor so you will need to pass those values.
  • You have to be prepared in case your coprocessor dies or crashes during match.

But this setup do have a lot of advantage. For example, if you write a custom vision stack in C++, having coprocessor controlling motors directly could means lower latency. But most of these don‚Äôt have a big enough community support as not a lot of team are using these. Still, these are interesting learning experience.

What happens if they fall off?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":48,"updated_at":"2024-09-11T04:55:06.116Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":274,"readers_count":273,"score":89.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":471033,"topic_slug":"controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio","display_username":"Ryan Blue","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio/471033/9","custom_user_title":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3422586,"name":"Sean","username":"wallefan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-11T07:26:18.391Z","cooked":"

@daltzsmith Thanks for this resource! I have successfully brought up the Pi HAT as a SocketCAN device and successfully communicated with my CTRE devices. I‚Äôve also successfully installed the CTRE phoenix6 Python library and gotten it to speak over the CAN bus. However, now I am facing a new problem.

When I open the Python interpreter and import the CTRE library, it initializes its diagnostic server which I can then connect to via Phoenix Tuner from another computer. From there, I can see the all the motor controllers connected to my Pi, and even turn the motors on. It all works great! The problem arises when I try to control the same motor via Python. I can create a TalonFX object in Python, and I can use it to read the motor voltage, encoder position, etc. of the motor (and I can verify that this works by spinning the motor with my fingers and noticing the value changes), but when I send a command from Python to start the motor, the CTRE library returns ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, but nothing happens. If I start the motor via Phoenix Tuner and try to stop it via Python, it keeps spinning.

I believe this is because I have to ‚Äúenable the robot‚Äù via Python somehow. How do I do this?

EDIT: never mind, I figured it out. I factory reset the motor controller to clear its FRC lock, and called phoenix6.unmanaged.feed_enable(...) to keep it running, as detailed here.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":48,"updated_at":"2024-09-11T07:42:22.634Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":266,"readers_count":265,"score":83.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":471033,"topic_slug":"controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio","display_username":"Sean","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/api-reference/api-usage/enabling-actuators.html#frc-lock","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Enabling Actuators","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67844,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/controlling-ctre-can-motor-controllers-directly-from-a-raspberry-pi-without-a-roborio/471033/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3422595,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-11T11:19:46.874Z","cooked":"

So you want a ‚ÄúTreadmill‚Äù style contact key. The system won‚Äôt power on if the magnetic key the user has clipped to them is removed from its proper spot. The clip has a shortish cord so if they fall off in theory it‚Äôll pull the clip away from the powered item with them and turn it off.

Of course this requires the user to actually use the clip properly (or not bypass it with another magnet), but at least you‚Äôre giving them a better way to stop, and if they choose to ignore it that‚Äôs on them.

71LznHfpwML.AC_UF1000,1000_QL80876√ó1000 66.8 KB

The red part is a magnet and picked up by a hall effect sensor/relay combo that will safely, but immediately decelerate the motor when it moves out of range (coast mode possibly), even if the main power is still active.

@daltzsmith Thanks for your help so far! I‚Äôve been able to successfully control some Talon FX motors from my Pi with no issues. However, these motors are expensive and in short supply around our lab, so we‚Äôd prefer to reserve them for robots we actually compete with. For an off-season robot designed purely for promotional purposes, we thought we‚Äôd reuse some Victor SPX motor controllers that we have lying around from previous seasons. Unfortunately these do not seem to be supported by the phoenix6 Python library at all, and installing the phoenix5 library on the Pi is proving difficult. I‚Äôve discovered that it seems to be packaged on PyPI under robotpy-ctre, however there is no ARM Linux build of the wpilib package on which it depends, and it will not install. Considering the RoboRIO itself is an ARM Linux computer, I am fairly certain such a build exists. Do you have any pointers as to how I would go about deploying it to my Pi?

CTRE didn‚Äôt support Python for phoenix 5, only C++ and Java. robotpy-ctre is wrappers provided by Robotpy around the Phoenix 5 c++ api.

You can still use phoenix 5 on a pi, but you‚Äôll have to use either c++ or java. More info here

amazon.com

Amazon.com: DSD TECH SH-C31A USB to CAN Adapter with FD Support based on Canable...

The SH-C31A is derived from the open source hardware project Canable 2.0, which differs from other commercial USB CAN products in that all the information (schematics, BOM list, Gerb files) is publicly available on the DSD TECH website. Also, if you...

$23.99
